front.title: Building Softwire in IPv6 Home Network

postal.street: Department of Computer Science, Tsinghua University
Department of Computer Science, Tsinghua University

abstract.t: In IPv6 home network, IPv4 service may still be needed for a long time. ISP can provider IPv4 service through IPv4-over-IPv6 softwire mechanisms, e.g. Dual-Stack Lite (). This document discusses how to build softwires from home routers, especially when there are multiple routers those are running distributed configuration and routing protocols.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: In IPv6 home network environments, when there are multiple routers, the routers are running distributed configuration and routing protocols. HNCP () is designed to configure home routers with IP prefixes and other information including stateless DHCPv6 options provided by ISPs. OSPFv3 () is used for IPv6 routing

As the IPv6 transition takes a long time and large cost, the demand of IPv4 service may still last for a long time and the ISP still needs to provide IPv4 service. To deal with the shortage of IPv4 addresses, several IPv4-over-IPv6 softwire mechanisms are proposed, e.g. Dual-Stack Lite (), MAP (), and Lightweight 4over6 (). The three mechanisms are similar in many aspects: provisioning specific information by DHCPv6, and IPv4 packets are transported in IPv4-in-IPv6 tunnels.

When ISP provides dual stack link to the homenet Edge Router, the Edge Router gets IPv4 address and performs NAT. The other home routers pick private IPv4 prefixes through HNCP, and the homenet runs OSPFv2 () to configure IPv4 routing. When ISP provides IPv6-only link and softwire service instead of dual stack, the same way - private IPv4 prefix + NAT and build softwire on Edge Router - still works. However, running OSPFv2 adds additional cost to the homenet. To remove OSPFv2, building softwire from all home routers is an alternative solution. And it's even possible to build softwire from end hosts.
This document discusses how homenet can build softwires in these methods, and discusses the compatibility with DS-Lite, MAP and Lightweight 4over6.

section.title: Terminology
section.t:
The document defines the following terms:
A home router that connects to ISP network. ISP can provision stateless DHCPv6 parameters to Edge Routers.
A home router that directly connects to end hosts.

section.title: Softwire Initiated by Inner Home Router
section.t: In this section we discuss how to build IPv4-over-IPv6 Softwire from every inner home router that connects to end hosts directly, which we call "End Routers". If a Edge Router that connects to ISP network also connects to some end hosts, it's also treated as a End Router.

To build softwire by End Routers, each router must get the information of the softwire, including the IPv6 address of remote tunnel endpoint, and other solution-specific information. All DS-Lite, MAP and Lightweight 4over6 use DHCPv6 option to provision softwire information. When the Edge Router receives a DHCPv6 response, it advertises the softwire information in DHCPv6 options to all routers through HNCP. When a inner home router receives the softwire information, it initiates an IPv4-in-IPv6 tunnel. In some solutions (e.g. Lightweight 4over6), the router needs to get more information before it builds the tunnel.

It's possible that the home net connects to multiple ISPs, and each ISP provides its own IPv6 prefix and softwire configuration to the same or different Edge Routers. In this case, the Edge Router(s) advertise each Softwire configuration to the homenet independently, and each Softwire configuration must be bound to the IPv6 prefix from the same ISP. The home routers set up their Softwires accordingly, and for each tunnel, the tunnel outer IPv6 addresses and inner IPv4 addresses must come the same ISP.

section.title: Running DS-Lite
section.t: In DS-Lite, all routers gets the AFTR-Name option () through HNCP. Each router chooses a private IPv4 prefix for its end users, and does not need to advertise the prefix to other routers. The routers build IPv4-in-IPv6 tunnel according to the AFTR-Name option, and routes all IPv4 traffic into the tunnel. The home routes do not perform NAT44.

section.title: Running MAP
section.t: In MAP-E, the ISP provides Softwire46 MAP-E Container Option () to the Edge Router. Then the whole container option is advertised through HNCP. Each router build MAP tunnel according to the option and its Assigned Prefix. The Assigned Prefix is treated as End-user prefix, thus the Delegated Prefix from ISP needs to be shorter than the expected End-user prefix, e.g. equals to Rule IPv6 prefix. The Edge Router calculates its public IPv4 address (and PSID) according to the MAP algorithm. Then the router performs NAT44, and routes all IPv4 traffic into the tunnel. Since all routers in the homenet shares a single MAP rule, the routers form (possibly part of) a single MAP domain. The ISP must provide enough IPv4 addresses for the homenet.

section.title: Running Lightweight 4over6
section.t: In Lightweight 4over6, the S46 IPv4/IPv6 Address Binding Option() inside the container option only contains IPv4 address for a single user. Thus it can not be used for configuring all home routers. DHCPv4 over DHCPv6 should be used for IPv4 provisioning. The S46 BR Option() and 4o6 Server Address Option() are received by Edge Router and advertised through HNCP. After obtained the two options, each router initiates DHCPv4 over DHCPv6 queries to get its IPv4 address, and perform NAT44 on the obtained address.

section.title: Softwire Initiated by Edge Router
section.t: IPv4-over-IPv6 Softwire can be initiated by Edge Router directly. ISPs provide their Softwire configuration information to the Edge Routers, and the Edge Routers build their Softwires directly. After setting up the Softwire successfully, a Edge Router chooses a private IPv4 prefix and advertise it to the homenet. Edge Routers running DS-Lite do not perform NAT44, and Edge Routers running MAP and Lightweight 4over6 perform NAT44. Private IPv4 prefix configuration is through HNCP, and OSPFv2 is used for routing.

section.title: Softwire Initiated by End Host
section.t: Softwire can also be initiated by end hosts. In this case, the Edge Routers advertise the Softwire Configuration information to the homenet as described in Section 3, but the routers do not set up Softwires. The routers need to configure their LAN side local provisioning protocol (e.g. DHCPv6) to provision the Softwire information to end hosts, and end hosts set up the tunnels accordingly.
End host needs to support the Softwire mechanisms. Since there could be various types of end hosts, including PCs, tablets or phones, and devices may run different OSs, it may not be easy to do this.

section.title: Discussion
section.t: In this draft we have discussed three possible scenarios to build IPv4-over-IPv6 Softwire in Homenet. The purpose of building softwire is to provide legacy IPv4 support for home users, and make it easier to transit the network to IPv6 and possible to shutdown IPv4.

Building Softwire from Edge Router is a native way that is quite close to dual-stack scenario. However, it requires IPv4 routing inside the home network, and requires IPv4 routing protocol. Once IPv4 routing is deployed in the home network, it's difficult to shut it down that even only few end devices require IPv4 service, all home routers need to run IPv4 routing protocol. It's solved by building softwire from End Routers that IPv4 routing protocol is not required in this case. Since IPv6 tunnel is built from end routers, there's no IPv4 traffic in the homenet and it could help the monitoring and network management. IPv4 service can be shut down at each routers, and it will not affect others routers.

Building Softwire form end hosts is possible, but not easy for large scale deployment because user devices are out of ISP's control. In most current home networks, there's already boxes from ISP or third-party. Dealing with routers is much easier for ISP to deploy their network.
According to the discussions, this draft recommends IPv6 home network to building IPv4-over-IPv6 Softwire from every End Routers, to support IPv4 service.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: This document does not define a new homenet or softwire mechanism. All the three scenarios are the combination of current mechanisms: HNCP, OSPF, and Softwire mechanisms: DS-Lite, MAP, and Lightweight 4over6. Security Considerations in these documents should be considered.
